channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Continues Bombardment, but Its Forces Have Shrunk, Pentagon Says
item.description: President Biden heads to Europe this week and will press allies for even more aggressive economic sanctions on Russia. Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian dissident, was sentenced to nine years in prison. Ukrainians said they had recaptured the strategic town of Makariv, west of Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rises north of Kyiv during a citywide curfew in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: No Survivors Found in China Eastern Plan Crash, Officials Say
item.description: Workers recovered identity cards, cellphones and purses from the crash site. But the plane’s steep plunge suggested there was a “minuscule” chance of any survivors, an expert said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: A piece of wreckage from Flight MU5735 that crashed into a hillside in Guangxi on Monday.

item.title: As Russia Stalls in Ukraine, Dissent Brews Over Putin’s Leadership
item.description: Military losses have mounted, progress has slowed, and a blame game has begun among some Russian supporters of the war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank after a battle north of Kyiv this month.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Outgunned Air Force Is Fighting Back Against Russian Jets
item.description: Aerial dogfights. Top Gun-style duels. Ukraine’s fighter pilots are badly outnumbered but have so far kept Russia from controlling the skies.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andriy, a Ukrainian Air Force pilot.“Every time when I fly, it’s for a real fight,” he said.

item.title: China Takes a Back Seat in International Diplomacy Over Ukraine
item.description: Despite its economic and military might and close ties to Russia, China has balked at trying to press Vladimir Putin to stop the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader Xi Jinping and President Vladimir Putin of Russia attending a meeting during the BRICS summit in Brasilia, Brazil, in 2019.

item.title: Aleksei Navalny Found Guilty of Fraud by Russian Court
item.description: Despite already being behind bars, Mr. Navalny has been urging Russians to protest the war in Ukraine, making him even more of a liability for President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny, standing at a desk, left, with his lawyers at a makeshift courtroom outside Moscow, as seen on a screen showing a video link from the hearing on Tuesday.

item.title: Leaders of Israel, U.A.E. and Egypt Meet Amid Shifting Geopolitics
item.description: All three countries are navigating fraught relationships with the Biden administration amid the quickly changing geopolitical landscape precipitated by Russia’s war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Gurkha Veterans Fight a Colonial-Era Legacy Still Shaping Nepal
item.description: Nepal’s best and brightest have been recruited while young to fight for Britain for over 200 years, with their pay and pensions a fraction of their fellow British soldiers’ for much of that time.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabin Mahat, 19, second from left, training to realize a lifelong dream: a spot in the British Army.

item.title: How Lviv Has Been Transformed by War
item.description: Simple rituals, like having coffee in a cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, take on a new and sometimes surreal meaning in a radically altered context.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: For millions of internally displaced people, Lviv is the gateway to safety, however fleeting, in the west.

item.title: Canada’s Trudeau Strikes Accord With Opponents to Secure Hold on Power
item.description: A left-of-center opposition party agrees to back the government until 2025 in exchange for advancing its causes.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Jagmeet Singh of the New Democratic Party during an election debate last September.

item.title: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s Prime Minister, Fights for Survival
item.description: Soaring inflation and a rift with the military threaten Imran Khan’s tenure as prime minister. He has dismissed criticism as a foreign conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Pakistan’s prime minister, Imran Khan, addressing the nation last month. A troubled economy and a rift with the military threaten his hold on power.

item.title: In Warsaw, a Network of Support Greets Those Crossing the Polish Border
item.description: A sprawling expo center in the Polish capital has given some 25,000 refugees a safe place to recharge before journeying on.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: An expo center on the outskirts of the Polish capital offers refugees a medical clinic, showers, toilets, charging stations, food and a place to shelter.

item.title: Tunisian President’s Reform Plan Meets With Skepticism
item.description: President Kais Saied, who has amassed nearly absolute power, launched a consultation he said would lead to a new constitution and elections. But the process has been shunned by many.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A protest rally in Tunis on Sunday against President Kais Saied of Tunisia. About 2,000 people gathered.

item.title: What We Know About the Crash of China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735
item.description: The crash of the Boeing plane, with more than 130 people on board, is China’s worst air disaster in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 planes at an airport in Taiyuan, Shanxi province, in 2014.

item.title: Yvan Colonna, Corsican Jailed for French Prefect’s Murder, Dies at 61
item.description: A folk hero for Corsica’s nationalist movement, he evaded a long manhunt but was finally arrested in 2003. He died shortly after being brutally attacked in prison.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A rally was held for the pro-independence activist Yvan Colonna in the Corsican city of Bastia this month after he was assaulted in prison, where he was serving a life sentence for murder.

item.title: Biden Heads to Europe Seeking to Bolster Russian Sanctions and Maintain Unity With Allies
item.description: A chief goal of the meetings this week is to show that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will not lead to sniping and disagreement among the United States and its allies.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden faces a steep challenge as he works to confront President Vladimir V. Putin’s aggression.

item.title: Ukraine War and Pandemic Force Nations to Retreat From Globalization
item.description: Conflicts among the U.S., Russia and China — and endless Covid-19 outbreaks — strain the interdependent economy and Western ideas of post-Cold War stability.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: A woman walks past a closed Louis Vuitton store in Moscow this week. Many American and European countries stopped doing business in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Extends Navalny’s Sentence
item.description: Plus Pfizer’s plan to send Covid pills to poor countries and efforts to unseat Pakistan’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Police officers detain an elderly woman as she protests against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, in central Moscow on March 20, 2022.

item.title: Russia’s Forces Against Ukraine Have Shrunk, Pentagon Says
item.description: The official said that Russian forces were “struggling on many fronts,” and that there were indications that some troops had been evacuated with frostbite.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces and civilians inspecting a disabled Russian tank this month. Russia has lost more than 10 percent of its original combat force in fighting Ukrainian troops.

item.title: Four Killed in Southern Israel in Latest in Spate of Attacks
item.description: The attacks have heightened fears of further violence in April, when the convergence of three religious holidays has leaders on edge.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A volunteer emergency response team cleans up the site of an attack in the southern Israeli city of Beersheba on Tuesday.

item.title: Vacations Abruptly End as Tourists Return to a Different Russia
item.description: While Russian tourists were visiting Margarita Island, their country invaded Ukraine. Many were left wondering what travails awaited them back at home.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The beach at Sunsol Ecoland hotel, a popular destination among Russian tourists, in Margarita, Venezuela.

item.title: ‘OK Doomer’ and the Climate Advocates Who Say It’s Not Too Late
item.description: A growing chorus of young people is focusing on climate solutions. “‘It’s too late’ means ‘I don’t have to do anything, and the responsibility is off me.’”
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Shirley Yu for The New York Times

item.title: Two Teachers Killed at a School in Malmo, Sweden
item.description: The police said they were still trying to determine a motive for the attack in the southern city of Malmo.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Johan Nilsson/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside Malmo Latin School in Malmo, Sweden, a day after two teachers were killed.

item.title: Here are the latest developments.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Why Ketanji Brown Jackson Is Different
item.description: Ketanji Brown Jackson is similar to and different from the justices she would be joining — not only because of her race and gender.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson during on Capitol Hill yesterday.

item.title: 1972: Millions of Workers Strike in Italy
item.description: Farm laborers, pressing demands including a shorter working week and a minimum wage, staged a 24-hour walkout. Refinery and filling station employees were also striking over pay and hours.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Mariupol refuses to surrender.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian serviceman guarding his position in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Condemns Russian Attacks on Protesters and Children
item.description: ‘It was a day of difficult events,’ the Ukrainian president said in a video address.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Video footage appears to show Russian troops firing into a crowd of protesters, some with Ukrainian flags, in Kherson, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Boeing Faces New Upheaval After Crash of Chinese Airliner
item.description: No fault has been found, but the company, which has been trying to overcome a recent legacy of design and production troubles, is likely to get scrutinized.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: A China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 aircraft in Wuhan, China, last year.

item.title: Russians Pound Ukrainian Cities, as Biden Rallies Anti-Kremlin Alliance
item.description: A powerful explosion ruined a shopping mall in Kyiv and claimed several lives, while Ukraine refused a Russian demand to surrender the devastated city of Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of the Retroville Mall after what appeared to be the most powerful explosion yet in the city of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: After China’s Worst Air Crash in Years, a Desperate Hunt for Survivors
item.description: The plane that crashed in a mountainous area of southern China was carrying 132 people, and no survivors have been found so far, a state broadcaster said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Vivek Shankar

item.title: High Death Rate in Hong Kong Shows Importance of Vaccinating the Elderly
item.description: Covid has surged in a number of Asian countries that had once held the virus at bay. Vaccination levels have largely determined how deadly those waves would be.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A community vaccination center last month in Hong Kong, whose older residents have relatively low rates of vaccination.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fight for Mariupol
item.description: Plus a plane crash in China and Hong Kong’s easing of Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Mariupol Residents Fight to Survive in Bombed and Besieged City
item.description: For three weeks, the Ukrainian port city has been without water, heat, electricity and all communication under a merciless Russian assault. Here’s what its residents have been enduring.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Biden Warns Private Sector of Potential Russian Cyberattacks
item.description: The president cited “evolving intelligence” and urged companies to strengthen their defenses immediately.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks at the White House in Washington last week.

item.title: Ask The Times Your Climate Questions
item.description: Wondering about a word, a scientific phenomenon, a policy or something else? We’re here to help.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Climate Desk
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times

item.title: As Big Shows of Russian Art End in Europe, Some Wonder What’s Next
item.description: Museums in London and Paris are grappling with questions about how to get art back to Russia, and whether the works will ever be seen again in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Vanessa Friedman
item.category: The Morozov Collection: Icons of Modern Art (Exhibit)

item.title: England Starts Giving Second Covid Boosters to Vulnerable People
item.description: People over 75, people living in nursing homes and anyone over 12 with a weakened immune system can now get a second booster dose six months after their first.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A National Health Service Covid-19 vaccination center in Blackburn, England, in January. The NHS will offer a fourth vaccine shot to vulnerable groups.

item.title: Myanmar’s Military Committed Genocide Against Rohingya, U.S. Says
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced the official designation. More than 9,000 people were killed in the violence.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees in Kashmir, India, in 2021. The violence in Myanmar’s Rakhine State peaked in August 2017 and forced nearly one million to flee the country.

item.title: Walls, Dreams and Genocide: Zelensky’s Speeches Invoke History to Rally Support
item.description: The Ukrainian leader, a former actor, has invoked emotional moments in the history of nations from which he is hoping to secure backing. We look at five of his recent speeches.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking virtually to the U.S. Congress last week. “Being the leader of the world means to be the leader of peace,” he said.

item.title: The Boeing 737-800 NG is widely used around the world.
item.description: The model involved in the China crash represents nearly 17 percent of the commercial aircraft in operation.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: A Delta Air Lines Boeing 737-800 NG commercial flight lands at New York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport in 2020.

item.title: U.N. Chief Warns of ‘Catastrophe’ With Continued Use of Fossil Fuels
item.description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said instead of replacing Russian oil, gas and coal, nations must pivot to clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: António Guterres, the U.N. Secretary General, at the organization's headquarters in New York City this month.

item.title: The Man in the Olive Green Tee
item.description: How President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine transformed the meaning of a piece of cotton.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: The Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky addresses the U.S. Congress via video link from Kyiv on March 16.

item.title: Plan for Amazon Headquarters in South Africa in Peril After Court Order
item.description: A judge ordered construction of the development in Cape Town to be halted, saying that the developer had not properly consulted Indigenous South Africans.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A judge’s order has put a hold on construction of Amazon’s African headquarters in Cape Town.

item.title: Back in U.K., Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Urges Iran to Release Others
item.description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, the British-Iranian charity worker held for six years in Tehran, said “freedom will never be complete” until all detainees were allowed to leave.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe at a Royal Air Force base in England last week after arriving from Iran, where she had been detained for six years.

item.title: Creating Space Command, Australia Strengthens High-Tech Bond With U.S.
item.description: The expanded commitment to space defense reflects the reality of a new, extraterrestrial landscape for war.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Minister Peter Dutton of Australia in January.

item.title: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on the War in Ukraine
item.description: Here are warning signs to look for before you retweet.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: People fleeing Ukraine at a border crossing in Slovakia. Experts in misinformation say everyone has a responsibility to verify information before sharing it.

item.title: Flight MU-5735 Descended More Than 20,000 Feet in Just Over a Minute
item.description: An hour after it took off, the flight turned horribly wrong, according to data from Flightradar24.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy

item.title: Farmers Describe Scene of China Eastern Airlines Plane Crash
item.description: Witnesses told Chinese news outlets they were at first baffled by the explosion in a rural area. Then, they realized the smoke was coming from what may be China’s worst air accident in decades.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Joy Dong
item.media:description: A still from a video on CCTV, China’s state television, showing emergency personnel preparing to travel to the site of a plane crash in southern China, on Monday.

item.title: The Plane That Crashed Was Not a Boeing 737 Max
item.description: The model is a narrow-body jet that has a maximum range of over 3,000 miles, but is commonly used on shorter routes.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 planes in Taiyuan, China, in 2014.

item.title: The Grimmest Dilemma
item.description: The Biden administration is facing an old Cold War dilemma: Be weak or risk a world war.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shelter in Kyiv.

item.title: China Eastern has not had a deadly crash in 18 years.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for the black boxes at the crash site of a China Eastern plane in Baotou, in China’s Inner Mongolia region, in 2004.

item.title: Boeing Stock Price Falls After China Eastern Crash
item.description: The aerospace giant said it was seeking more information on the disaster, and U.S. regulators said they were ready to assist.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: The Hong Kong stock index on Monday. China Eastern shares finished lower after the crash.

item.title: The Overlooked Stone Carvers of Escolásticas
item.description: A small town in Central Mexico is home to around 200 open-air carving workshops, from which an astonishing array of sculptures continuously emerges.
item.dc:creator: Walter Hodges

item.title: Japan Saved Red-Crowned Cranes. Can They Survive Without Humans?
item.description: Conservators vastly increased the numbers of red-crowned cranes, a symbol of loyalty and longevity in Japanese culture. That’s just a start.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Hikari Hida and James Whitlow Delano
item.media:credit: James Whitlow Delano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red-crowned cranes dancing together in Kushiro.

item.title: As Inflation Surges, Biden Targets Ocean Shipping
item.description: The president is targeting shipping companies that have jacked up prices during the pandemic, but critics say bigger economic forces are at work.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Coley Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cost to ship a container to the West Coast from China is 12 times higher than it was two years ago.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia pummels Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A satellite image showing the damage to the Mariupol Drama Theater.
